title: Conc. of sulfate constant - CuSO4 soln evaporates

content.description: The saturated <math alttext="C u S O 4, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CuS</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> shown above is left uncovered on a lab bench at a constant temperature. As the solution evaporates, <math alttext="1.0 milliliter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> samples of the solution are removed every three days and the <math alttext="molar concentration of S O 4 with a negative 2 charge" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <msup> <mrow> <mo stretchy="false">[</mo> <mtext>S</mtext> <msub> <mrow> <mtext>O</mtext> </mrow> <mrow> <mn>4</mn> </mrow> </msub> </mrow> <mrow> <mn>2</mn> <mo>−</mo> </mrow> </msup> <mo stretchy="false">]</mo> </mrow> </mstyle> </math> in the samples is measured. It is observed that the <math alttext="molar concentration of S O 4 with a negative 2 charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>[S</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> in the solution did not change over time.
content.question: Which of the following best helps to explain the observation?

choices.label: As the solution evaporates, <math alttext="C u with a positive 2 charge, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Cu</mtext></mrow><mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="S O 4 with a negative 2 charge, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>S</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> leave the beaker along with the water molecules.

As the solution evaporates, the dissolution of <math alttext="C u S O 4, solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CuS</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> in the beaker decreases.

The evaporation of water is endothermic, so more <math alttext="C u S O 4, solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CuS</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> dissolves exothermically in the solution, which increases the <math alttext="molar concentration of S O 4 with a negative 2 charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>[S</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>.

As water evaporates, more <math alttext="C u S O 4, solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CuS</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> precipitates out of the solution in the beaker.

content.answer: As water evaporates, more <math alttext="C u S O 4, solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CuS</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> precipitates out of the solution in the beaker.

skill.text: 6.F: Explain the connection between experimental results and chemical concepts, processes, or theories.
